an9.32:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these nine progressive meditations.

an9.32:1.3.pli: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ, dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ, tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ, catutthaṃ jhānaṃ, ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ, viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ, ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ, saññāvedayitanirodho—
an9.32:1.3.eng: The first absorption, the second absorption, the third absorption, the fourth absorption, the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness, the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and the cessation of perception and feeling.

an9.32:1.4.eng: These are the nine progressive meditations.”

an9.33:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the nine progressive meditative attainments …

an9.33:1.2.eng: And what are the nine progressive meditative attainments?

an9.33:1.3.pli: Yattha kāmā nirujjhanti, ye ca kāme nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti, ‘addhā te āyasmanto nicchātā nibbutā tiṇṇā pāraṅgatā tadaṅgenā’ti vadāmi.
an9.33:1.3.eng: Where sensual pleasures cease, and those who have thoroughly ended sensual pleasures meditate, I say: ‘Clearly those venerables are desireless, quenched, crossed over, and gone beyond in that respect.’

an9.33:1.4.pli: ‘Kattha kāmā nirujjhanti, ke ca kāme nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti—
an9.33:1.4.eng: If someone should say, ‘I do not know or see where sensual pleasures cease’,

an9.33:1.5.pli: ahametaṃ na jānāmi ahametaṃ na passāmī’ti, iti yo evaṃ vadeyya, so evamassa vacanīyo:

an9.33:1.6.pli: ‘idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.33:1.6.eng: ‘Reverend, it’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an9.33:1.7.pli: Ettha kāmā nirujjhanti, te ca kāme nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharantī’ti.

an9.33:1.8.pli: Addhā, bhikkhave, asaṭho amāyāvī ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinandeyya anumodeyya;
an9.33:1.8.eng: Clearly someone who is not devious or deceitful would approve and agree with that statement.

an9.33:1.9.pli: ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā namassamāno pañjaliko payirupāseyya.
an9.33:1.9.eng: They’d say ‘Good!’ and bowing down, they’d pay homage with joined palms.

an9.33:2.1.pli: Yattha vitakkavicārā nirujjhanti, ye ca vitakkavicāre nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti, ‘addhā te āyasmanto nicchātā nibbutā tiṇṇā pāraṅgatā tadaṅgenā’ti vadāmi.
an9.33:2.1.eng: Where the placing of the mind and keeping it connected cease, and those who have thoroughly ended the placing of the mind and keeping it connected meditate, I say: ‘Clearly those venerables are desireless, quenched, crossed over, and gone beyond in that respect.’

an9.33:2.2.pli: ‘Kattha vitakkavicārā nirujjhanti, ke ca vitakkavicāre nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti—
an9.33:2.2.eng: If someone should say, ‘I do not know or see where the placing of the mind and keeping it connected cease’,

an9.33:2.3.pli: ahametaṃ na jānāmi ahametaṃ na passāmī’ti, iti yo evaṃ vadeyya, so evamassa vacanīyo:

an9.33:2.4.pli: ‘idhāvuso, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
an9.33:2.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

an9.33:2.5.pli: ettha vitakkavicārā nirujjhanti, te ca vitakkavicāre nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharantī’ti.
an9.33:2.5.eng: That’s where the placing of the mind and keeping it connected cease.’

an9.33:2.6.pli: Addhā, bhikkhave, asaṭho amāyāvī ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinandeyya anumodeyya;
an9.33:2.6.eng: Clearly someone who is not devious or deceitful would approve and agree with that statement.

an9.33:2.7.pli: ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā namassamāno pañjaliko payirupāseyya.
an9.33:2.7.eng: They’d say ‘Good!’ and bowing down, they’d pay homage with joined palms.

an9.33:3.1.pli: Yattha pīti nirujjhati, ye ca pītiṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti, ‘addhā te āyasmanto nicchātā nibbutā tiṇṇā pāraṅgatā tadaṅgenā’ti vadāmi.
an9.33:3.1.eng: Where rapture ceases, and those who have thoroughly ended rapture meditate, I say: ‘Clearly those venerables are desireless, quenched, crossed over, and gone beyond in that respect.’

an9.33:3.2.pli: ‘Kattha pīti nirujjhati, ke ca pītiṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti—
an9.33:3.2.eng: If someone should say, ‘I do not know or see where rapture ceases’,

an9.33:3.3.pli: ahametaṃ na jānāmi ahametaṃ na passāmī’ti, iti yo evaṃ vadeyya, so evamassa vacanīyo:

an9.33:3.4.pli: ‘idhāvuso, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
an9.33:3.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, with the fading away of rapture, enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, “Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss”.

an9.33:3.5.pli: ettha pīti nirujjhati, te ca pītiṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharantī’ti.

an9.33:3.6.pli: Addhā, bhikkhave, asaṭho amāyāvī ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinandeyya anumodeyya;
an9.33:3.6.eng: Clearly someone who is not devious or deceitful would approve and agree with that statement.

an9.33:3.7.pli: ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā namassamāno pañjaliko payirupāseyya.
an9.33:3.7.eng: They’d say ‘Good!’ and bowing down, they’d pay homage with joined palms.

an9.33:4.1.pli: Yattha upekkhāsukhaṃ nirujjhati, ye ca upekkhāsukhaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti, ‘addhā te āyasmanto nicchātā nibbutā tiṇṇā pāraṅgatā tadaṅgenā’ti vadāmi.
an9.33:4.1.eng: Where bliss with equanimity ceases, and those who have thoroughly ended bliss with equanimity meditate, I say: ‘Clearly those venerables are desireless, quenched, crossed over, and gone beyond in that respect.’

an9.33:4.2.pli: ‘Kattha upekkhāsukhaṃ nirujjhati, ke ca upekkhāsukhaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti—
an9.33:4.2.eng: If someone should say, ‘I do not know or see where bliss with equanimity ceases’,

an9.33:4.3.pli: ahametaṃ na jānāmi ahametaṃ na passāmī’ti, iti yo evaṃ vadeyya, so evamassa vacanīyo:

an9.33:4.4.pli: ‘idhāvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati;
an9.33:4.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

an9.33:4.5.pli: ettha upekkhāsukhaṃ nirujjhati, te ca upekkhāsukhaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharantī’ti.
an9.33:4.5.eng: That’s where bliss with equanimity ceases.’

an9.33:4.6.pli: Addhā, bhikkhave, asaṭho amāyāvī ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinandeyya anumodeyya;
an9.33:4.6.eng: Clearly someone who is not devious or deceitful would approve and agree with that statement.

an9.33:4.7.pli: ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā namassamāno pañjaliko payirupāseyya.
an9.33:4.7.eng: They’d say ‘Good!’ and bowing down, they’d pay homage with joined palms.

an9.33:5.1.pli: Yattha rūpasaññā nirujjhati, ye ca rūpasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti, ‘addhā te āyasmanto nicchātā nibbutā tiṇṇā pāraṅgatā tadaṅgenā’ti vadāmi.
an9.33:5.1.eng: Where perceptions of form ceases, and those who have thoroughly ended perceptions of form meditate, I say: ‘Clearly those venerables are desireless, quenched, crossed over, and gone beyond in that respect.’

an9.33:5.2.pli: ‘Kattha rūpasaññā nirujjhati, ke ca rūpasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti—
an9.33:5.2.eng: If someone should say, ‘I do not know or see where perceptions of form ceases’,

an9.33:5.3.pli: ahametaṃ na jānāmi ahametaṃ na passāmī’ti, iti yo evaṃ vadeyya, so evamassa vacanīyo:

an9.33:5.4.pli: ‘idhāvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ananto ākāsoti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.33:5.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that “space is infinite”, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

an9.33:5.5.pli: Ettha rūpasaññā nirujjhati, te ca rūpasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharantī’ti.
an9.33:5.5.eng: That’s where perceptions of form cease.’

an9.33:5.6.pli: Addhā, bhikkhave, asaṭho amāyāvī ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinandeyya anumodeyya;
an9.33:5.6.eng: Clearly someone who is not devious or deceitful would approve and agree with that statement.

an9.33:5.7.pli: ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā namassamāno pañjaliko payirupāseyya.
an9.33:5.7.eng: They’d say ‘Good!’ and bowing down, they’d pay homage with joined palms.

an9.33:6.1.pli: Yattha ākāsānañcāyatanasaññā nirujjhati, ye ca ākāsānañcāyatanasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti, ‘addhā te āyasmanto nicchātā nibbutā tiṇṇā pāraṅgatā tadaṅgenā’ti vadāmi.
an9.33:6.1.eng: Where the perception of the dimension of infinite space ceases, and those who have thoroughly ended the perception of the dimension of infinite space meditate, I say: ‘Clearly those venerables are desireless, quenched, crossed over, and gone beyond in that respect.’

an9.33:6.2.pli: ‘Kattha ākāsānañcāyatanasaññā nirujjhati, ke ca ākāsānañcāyatanasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti—
an9.33:6.2.eng: If someone should say, ‘I do not know or see where the perception of the dimension of infinite space ceases’,

an9.33:6.3.pli: ahametaṃ na jānāmi ahametaṃ na passāmī’ti, iti yo evaṃ vadeyya, so evamassa vacanīyo:

an9.33:6.4.pli: ‘idhāvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma anantaṃ viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.33:6.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that “consciousness is infinite”, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

an9.33:6.5.pli: Ettha ākāsānañcāyatanasaññā nirujjhati, te ca ākāsānañcāyatanasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharantī’ti.
an9.33:6.5.eng: That’s where the perception of the dimension of infinite space ceases.’

an9.33:6.6.pli: Addhā, bhikkhave, asaṭho amāyāvī ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinandeyya anumodeyya;
an9.33:6.6.eng: Clearly someone who is not devious or deceitful would approve and agree with that statement.

an9.33:6.7.pli: ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā namassamāno pañjaliko payirupāseyya.
an9.33:6.7.eng: They’d say ‘Good!’ and bowing down, they’d pay homage with joined palms.

an9.33:7.1.pli: Yattha viññāṇañcāyatanasaññā nirujjhati, ye ca viññāṇañcāyatanasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti, ‘addhā te āyasmanto nicchātā nibbutā tiṇṇā pāraṅgatā tadaṅgenā’ti vadāmi.
an9.33:7.1.eng: Where the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness ceases, and those who have thoroughly ended the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness meditate, I say: ‘Clearly those venerables are desireless, quenched, crossed over, and gone beyond in that respect.’

an9.33:7.2.pli: ‘Kattha viññāṇañcāyatanasaññā nirujjhati, ke ca viññāṇañcāyatanasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti—
an9.33:7.2.eng: If someone should say, ‘I do not know or see where the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness ceases’,

an9.33:7.3.pli: ahametaṃ na jānāmi ahametaṃ na passāmī’ti, iti yo evaṃ vadeyya, so evamassa vacanīyo:

an9.33:7.4.pli: ‘idhāvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma natthi kiñcīti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.33:7.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that “there is nothing at all”, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.

an9.33:7.5.pli: Ettha viññāṇañcāyatanasaññā nirujjhati, te ca viññāṇañcāyatanasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharantī’ti.
an9.33:7.5.eng: That’s where the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness ceases.’

an9.33:7.6.pli: Addhā, bhikkhave, asaṭho amāyāvī ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinandeyya anumodeyya;
an9.33:7.6.eng: Clearly someone who is not devious or deceitful would approve and agree with that statement.

an9.33:7.7.pli: ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā namassamāno pañjaliko payirupāseyya.
an9.33:7.7.eng: They’d say ‘Good!’ and bowing down, they’d pay homage with joined palms.

an9.33:8.1.pli: Yattha ākiñcaññāyatanasaññā nirujjhati, ye ca ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti, ‘addhā te āyasmanto nicchātā nibbutā tiṇṇā pāraṅgatā tadaṅgenā’ti vadāmi.
an9.33:8.1.eng: Where the perception of the dimension of nothingness ceases, and those who have thoroughly ended the perception of the dimension of nothingness meditate, I say: ‘Clearly those venerables are desireless, quenched, crossed over, and gone beyond in that respect.’

an9.33:8.2.pli: ‘Kattha ākiñcaññāyatanasaññā nirujjhati, ke ca ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti—
an9.33:8.2.eng: If someone should say, ‘I do not know or see where the perception of the dimension of nothingness ceases’,

an9.33:8.3.pli: ahametaṃ na jānāmi ahametaṃ na passāmī’ti, iti yo evaṃ vadeyya, so evamassa vacanīyo:

an9.33:8.4.pli: ‘idhāvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.33:8.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

an9.33:8.5.pli: Ettha ākiñcaññāyatanasaññā nirujjhati, te ca ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharantī’ti.
an9.33:8.5.eng: That’s where the perception of the dimension of nothingness ceases.’

an9.33:8.6.pli: Addhā, bhikkhave, asaṭho amāyāvī ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinandeyya anumodeyya;
an9.33:8.6.eng: Clearly someone who is not devious or deceitful would approve and agree with that statement.

an9.33:8.7.pli: ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā namassamāno pañjaliko payirupāseyya.
an9.33:8.7.eng: They’d say ‘Good!’ and bowing down, they’d pay homage with joined palms.

an9.33:9.1.pli: Yattha nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññā nirujjhati, ye ca nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti, ‘addhā te āyasmanto nicchātā nibbutā tiṇṇā pāraṅgatā tadaṅgenā’ti vadāmi.
an9.33:9.1.eng: Where the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception ceases, and those who have thoroughly ended the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception meditate, I say: ‘Clearly those venerables are desireless, quenched, crossed over, and gone beyond in that respect.’

an9.33:9.2.pli: ‘Kattha nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññā nirujjhati, ke ca nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharanti—
an9.33:9.2.eng: If someone should say, ‘I do not know or see where the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception ceases’,

an9.33:9.3.pli: ahametaṃ na jānāmi ahametaṃ na passāmī’ti, iti yo evaṃ vadeyya, so evamassa vacanīyo:

an9.33:9.4.pli: ‘idhāvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.33:9.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling.

an9.33:9.5.pli: Ettha nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññā nirujjhati, te ca nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññaṃ nirodhetvā nirodhetvā viharantī’ti.
an9.33:9.5.eng: That’s where the perception of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception ceases.’

an9.33:9.6.pli: Addhā, bhikkhave, asaṭho amāyāvī ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinandeyya anumodeyya;
an9.33:9.6.eng: Clearly someone who is not devious or deceitful would approve and agree with that statement.

an9.33:9.7.pli: ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā namassamāno pañjaliko payirupāseyya.
an9.33:9.7.eng: They’d say ‘Good!’ and bowing down, they’d pay homage with joined palms.

an9.33:10.1.eng: These are the nine progressive meditative attainments.”

an9.34:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā sāriputto rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
an9.34:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

an9.34:1.2.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:

an9.34:1.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā udāyī āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an9.34:1.5.eng: When he said this, Venerable Udāyī said to him,

an9.34:1.6.pli: “kiṃ panettha, āvuso sāriputta, sukhaṃ yadettha natthi vedayitan”ti?
an9.34:1.6.eng: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what’s blissful about it, since nothing is felt?”

an9.34:1.7.pli: “Etadeva khvettha, āvuso, sukhaṃ yadettha natthi vedayitaṃ.
an9.34:1.7.eng: “The fact that nothing is felt is precisely what’s blissful about it.

an9.34:1.8.eng: Reverend, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

an9.34:1.10.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
an9.34:1.10.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

an9.34:1.14.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā—
an9.34:1.14.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

an9.34:1.15.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

an9.34:1.16.pli: Yaṃ kho, āvuso, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, idaṃ vuccatāvuso, kāmasukhaṃ.
an9.34:1.16.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure.

an9.34:2.1.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.34:2.1.eng: First, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures … enters and remains in the first absorption.

an9.34:2.2.pli: Tassa ce, āvuso, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato kāmasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti, svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:2.2.eng: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if perception and focus accompanied by sensual pleasures beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:2.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.34:2.3.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.34:2.4.pli: evamevassa te kāmasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:2.4.eng: In the same way, should perception and focus accompanied by sensual pleasures beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:2.5.pli: Yo kho panāvuso, ābādho dukkhametaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā.
an9.34:2.5.eng: And affliction has been called suffering by the Buddha.

an9.34:2.6.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sukhaṃ nibbānaṃ.
an9.34:2.6.eng: That’s the way to understand how extinguishment is bliss.

an9.34:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.34:3.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption.

an9.34:3.2.pli: Tassa ce, āvuso, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato vitakkasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti, svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:3.2.eng: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if perception and focus accompanied by placing of the mind beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:3.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.34:3.3.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.34:3.4.pli: evamevassa te vitakkasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:3.4.eng: In the same way, should perception and focus accompanied by placing of the mind beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:3.5.pli: Yo kho panāvuso, ābādho dukkhametaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā.
an9.34:3.5.eng: And affliction has been called suffering by the Buddha.

an9.34:3.6.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sukhaṃ nibbānaṃ.
an9.34:3.6.eng: That too is a way to understand how extinguishment is bliss.

an9.34:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.34:4.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, with the fading away of rapture, enters and remains in the third absorption.

an9.34:4.2.pli: Tassa ce, āvuso, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato pītisahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti, svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:4.2.eng: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if perception and focus accompanied by rapture beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:4.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.34:4.3.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.34:4.4.pli: evamevassa te pītisahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:4.4.eng: In the same way, should perception and focus accompanied by rapture beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:4.5.pli: Yo kho panāvuso, ābādho dukkhametaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā.
an9.34:4.5.eng: And affliction has been called suffering by the Buddha.

an9.34:4.6.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sukhaṃ nibbānaṃ.
an9.34:4.6.eng: That too is a way to understand how extinguishment is bliss.

an9.34:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.34:5.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, enters and remains in the fourth absorption.

an9.34:5.2.pli: Tassa ce, āvuso, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato upekkhāsahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti, svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:5.2.eng: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if perception and focus accompanied by bliss with equanimity beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:5.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.34:5.3.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.34:5.4.pli: evamevassa te upekkhāsahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:5.4.eng: In the same way, should perception and focus accompanied by bliss with equanimity beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:5.5.pli: Yo kho panāvuso, ābādho dukkhametaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā.
an9.34:5.5.eng: And affliction has been called suffering by the Buddha.

an9.34:5.6.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sukhaṃ nibbānaṃ.
an9.34:5.6.eng: That too is a way to understand how extinguishment is bliss.

an9.34:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ananto ākāsoti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.34:6.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

an9.34:6.2.pli: Tassa ce, āvuso, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato rūpasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti, svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:6.2.eng: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if perception and focus accompanied by form beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:6.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.34:6.3.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.34:6.4.pli: evamevassa te rūpasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:6.4.eng: In the same way, should perception and focus accompanied by form beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:6.5.pli: Yo kho panāvuso, ābādho dukkhametaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā.
an9.34:6.5.eng: And affliction has been called suffering by the Buddha.

an9.34:6.6.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sukhaṃ nibbānaṃ.
an9.34:6.6.eng: That too is a way to understand how extinguishment is bliss.

an9.34:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma anantaṃ viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.34:7.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

an9.34:7.2.pli: Tassa ce, āvuso, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato ākāsānañcāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti, svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:7.2.eng: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if perception and focus accompanied by the dimension of infinite space beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:7.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.34:7.3.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.34:7.4.pli: evamevassa te ākāsānañcāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:7.4.eng: In the same way, should perception and focus accompanied by the dimension of infinite space beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:7.5.pli: Yo kho panāvuso, ābādho dukkhametaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā.
an9.34:7.5.eng: And affliction has been called suffering by the Buddha.

an9.34:7.6.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sukhaṃ nibbānaṃ.
an9.34:7.6.eng: That too is a way to understand how extinguishment is bliss.

an9.34:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma, natthi kiñcīti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.34:8.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.

an9.34:8.2.pli: Tassa ce, āvuso, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato viññāṇañcāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti, svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:8.2.eng: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if perception and focus accompanied by the dimension of infinite consciousness beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:8.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.34:8.3.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.34:8.4.pli: evamevassa te viññāṇañcāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:8.4.eng: In the same way, should perception and focus accompanied by the dimension of infinite consciousness beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:8.5.pli: Yo kho panāvuso, ābādho dukkhametaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā.
an9.34:8.5.eng: And affliction has been called suffering by the Buddha.

an9.34:8.6.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sukhaṃ nibbānaṃ.
an9.34:8.6.eng: That too is a way to understand how extinguishment is bliss.

an9.34:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an9.34:9.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

an9.34:9.2.pli: Tassa ce, āvuso, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato ākiñcaññāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti, svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:9.2.eng: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if perception and focus accompanied by the dimension of nothingness beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:9.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, sukhino dukkhaṃ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya;
an9.34:9.3.eng: Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

an9.34:9.4.pli: evamevassa te ākiñcaññāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti. Svassa hoti ābādho.
an9.34:9.4.eng: In the same way, should perception and focus accompanied by the dimension of nothingness beset them, that’s an affliction for them.

an9.34:9.5.pli: Yo kho panāvuso, ābādho dukkhametaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā.
an9.34:9.5.eng: And affliction has been called suffering by the Buddha.

an9.34:9.6.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sukhaṃ nibbānaṃ.
an9.34:9.6.eng: That too is a way to understand how extinguishment is bliss.

an9.34:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
an9.34:10.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

an9.34:11.1.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, āvuso, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sukhaṃ nibbānan”ti.
an9.34:11.1.eng: That too is a way to understand how extinguishment is bliss.”
